conclusion: Shadows are created when an object blocks light from a source, and their size and position depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
The image shows four objects casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D.
The light source is currently positioned such that the shadows are cast to the left of the objects.

premise: When the light source moves to the right, the shadows will shift to the left relative to their current positions.
conclusion: The shadows will shift to the left because the light now comes from a more rightward direction, causing the shadows to be cast in the opposite direction.

premise: The degree of shift will depend on how far the light source is moved.
conclusion: The shadows will shift more if the light source is moved further to the right.
